titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the James Wilder Green Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Christine Connolly and Laura Tatum

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Friday April 5, 2019 at 07:31

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright interests of the donor, Nancy T. Park, the niece of James Wilder Green, have been transferred to Yale University. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: James Wilder Green Papers (MS 1891). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: James Wilder Green (1927-2005) was an American architect and arts administrator. He received his bachelor of architecture degree from Yale in 1952. For twenty-five years, he sat on the board of The MacDowell Colony, and was director of the American Federation of the Arts from 1971 to 1987. He was also a longtime staff member at the Museum of Modern Art, beginning in 1956 in the Department of Architecture and Design as assistant to Alfred Barr and becoming head of the Department of Exhibitions from 1967 to 1970.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The James Wilder Green papers document Green's architectural commissions from 1950-2003. While Green never worked full-time as an architect, he was trained at Yale by Louis Kahn and apprenticed with Philip Johnson in New York and Paul Rudolph in Florida. His services as a residential and furniture designer were in demand by friends and family, and he also redesigned several galleries and museum exhibition spaces.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids
otherfindaid.p: For a list of projects and the boxes in which project materials are located, please consult the Project Index.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The papers are arranged in two series: Series I, Personal Papers, and Series II, Project Records.

controlaccess.subject: Architecture -- 20th Century -- United States
controlaccess.corpname: Museum of Modern Art (New York, N.Y.)

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Items are listed by type of material.

did.unittitle: Writing: Green, James Wilder, "Architecture in Theaters" in Chrysalis

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Material is arranged alphabetically by project/client name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists primarily of architectural drawings and sketches. The clients for which project materials are contained in the series are listed below. See the attached project index for box numbers and other project information.
